column13: FIGURE IT OUT AND ITS A GREAT GAME
column14:
First and foremost, this game isn't MOOII. It never reaches the excellence of that game. It isn't a one star game though. I have spent many hours playing this game now and still do from time to time. Once you figure out how to play the game, how to manage the intricacies of the interface, it can actually be quite fun. Most of the points against the game concerning micro-management are not a big deal. By the middle of the game you could potentially have hundreds of planets but really only a dozen or so that you really care about. If some systems spam produce troop ships or infantry, so what, as far as I know, there is no limit on how many ships or troops you can have available. The star systems and planets are fantastic to look at and the variations really make the initial exploration of the galaxy a blast. If you get sick of colonizing, you can tell the AI to auto-colonize as colony ships become available. Your race characteristics determine what planets are habitable I believe, but most of the new races suck. My biggest beef with the game is the elimination of several of the really cool races from MOOII, but you can find them as magnate civilization specials on some planets. Troops built on these planets will appear with different pictures, which is a small but very cool addition. Diplomacy is pretty stupid, and pointless, since your allies will colonize any planets you haven't taken in your star systems. Very frustrating. Once your planets gain max population, they will begin auto-colonizing other less desirable planets in-system or even in other near by systems. There's a lot of small things like this that show this game is much better than most people make it. The race building and galaxy creation are good, though many of the race selections aren't things that obviously show up in the game, mostly background macros that you will never see.

Technology is pretty simple but it works, though again what certain techs do is not obvious in the game but morebackground. You can have up to two DEAs in each sector of your planet. You get to choose which go in each sector but what alluvial, hard scrabble, fertile, etc and the terrain of it actually does to the output is unknown. Other than your first few planets, you aren't going to care about this and will let the AI take over based on the colonies needs. Again, you will only care about a few planets or systems by the middle of the game. You will be busy extinguishing all the other races. People complain about the interface, but most of the interface comes down to a few buttons to give the AI orders. Some things like forced labor don't do anything to change the game that I am aware of, Other things like the oppressometer are essential to weed out enemy spies, though at the cost of some rebellions.

The Good:
The game is beautiful and functional. I haven't had any problems with bugs or crashing. Any game that is playable deserves some credit.
The game is complicated. A lot of the griping about the game is probably coming from people who didn't figure out how to control the AI.
The game is fun and has a high replay ability in my experience. Stick with it and you'll figure it out.
The races feel more balanced than from MOOII when you were always fighting Saakra and Klakon.

The Bad:
All the races that I hated from MOOII survived and none of the ones I loved made it.
The espionage is terrible. You will pull your hair out as techs are constantly stolen from you. The leaders are cool and diverse but seem to always get killed by enemy spies before they really help you out. I think spies in your que can be on defense so maybe that helps but it's very clunky.
At a certain point in the game you are unstoppable but that still doesn't help you find Antaran X's. I have never managed to find more than one of them. This may just be because I'm not building ships with the right equipment. if that's the case, the game doesn't explainthat, in fact it doesn't explain much at tall.
I absolutely hate when other races colonize planets in systems you control. I know this comes down to colonizing algorithms in the game's AI but it's stupid and frustrating. You can stop the colonizing by having a fleet in the system at least.

This game is not as bad as some make it out to be. If you quit too soon you will never get it. If you give it a chance it will surprise you. It's not a one star or a five star game, but it is fun to play if you take the time to figure it out.

column13: It's pretty, but just an okay game
column14:
This game has one thing going for it. It has some really nice graphics. However, it is also a very dark game - dark as in it's very hard to see what is going on on the screen at times because I can barely see it. I would think I just need to adjust the brightness, but other parts of the game are just perfect and I have no issues. This game has a LOT of cut scenes. I really don't mind cut scenes, especially when the graphics are so nice, however it makes it feel like the actual game play time is quite short.

Unfortunately, this game does not have a finished polish to it. There are a few additional issues that I wouldn't expect in a $60 video game. First, there were some very obvious issues with the timing of the voices and movement of the characters mouths - think bad Kung Fu movie dubbed in English. I also had an issue with the game loading at the end of Chapter 1. The loading screen froze and I had to go and replay the previous scene several times to force the next scene to load properly.

This game is NOT one of those open ended games - Assassins Creed, Dying Light, etc. You can't just go around and explore. Yes, there are several hidden items you can find, but the game is VERY linear. There is no map system because you can only go one path, you just keep going until you get where it wants you to go. You can't interact with NPC's. Walking past NPC's in the street. they will ignore you as if you aren't even there.

I have to say overall I'm glad I only paid $20 for this game during Amazon's "Black Friday" sale. The graphics are really nice, but the game/story line really haven't kept my interest. I've had the game for about a month and have only played 2 times.

column14:
I have had this remote, and have been using it regularly, for the past four years.

As I see it, there are two important conclusions I have made.

The first is that in terms of its functionality as a DVD/Blu-Ray/media playback remote for PS3, it works wonderfully. Period. It's a great remote in that respect.

The second is that whoever was responsible for the design of its size and shape and button layout should be fired, because there are two MAJOR problems with it that make it SUPER ANNOYING, whenever you use it: 1. the size and shape is bizarre; it is thin and the bottom is curved, so holding it (if you have large hands, as I do) is awkward, and if the remote is resting on a flat surface and you attempt to push a button on it without picking it up first, it teeters to one side or the other because of the curve, and therefore will not take the input. 2. The MOST irritating thing about this remote is the fact that wherever it is, whenever you pick it up - and especially when you are only moving it or something, and not intending to turn on or use your PS3 - because of the centrally located PS button, and its sensitivity, you will INVARIABLY accidentally push it, thus turning on the PS3 accidentally, when you didn't intend to, resulting in having to go through the hassle of turning on your TV, changing the input to PS3, and going through the 2 or 3 button pushes required to turn the thing off again, because of course it's not like a basic Blu-Ray player with a simple 'power' on/off button....After countless times over the years having to go through that waste of time turning off the PS3 after accidentally turning it on, I finally got fed up and threw this remote away, and went back to using the Dualshock controller, instead. I just hope whoever designs a PS4 remote reads this review, first...

column13: The Best Android Tv Device Yet!
column14:
The nvidia shield tv is finally here, and while this is a new type of Android device for the Nvidia team, they have really knocked it out of the park with this one. The nvidia shield tv is the third device in the shield line up, starting with the recently renamed shield portable, the shield tablet, and now the shield tv. The shield tv runs a customised version of android, called android tv. Android tv is a skinned version of android that provides access to all your games, media content, and apps on an easy to use interface that can be controlled with either a remote, or a game pad. Once you open up the box, and get everything plugged in and boot up the device, you will be asked to pair up the included shield controller. This controller is wonderful, light weight, with very responsive controls and analog sticks, and of course it is wireless via wifi-direct to allow super low latency. The controller chargers from an included usb cable, much like most smartphones today use. The battery life is decent at best, you can get about a day and a half with heavy useage. The shield tv has multiple ways to get games and apps, the first is through the play store. The play store is included on the device and has a nicely redone design just for android tv, which sorts out apps and games into multiple categories. The down side is that while there are a ton of games, there is no where near as many games or apps as the playstore on phones has, this is because the android tv play store only allows games or apps on the store that support controllers and remotes. The second option, is sideloading. I won't go into too much detail on this, but if there is an app or game that supports controllers and isn't on the android tv play store, then you can sideload it to play on the shield tv. The third option, is trying out grid streaming. This wonderful free feature for the time being, allows you to stream full-featured games such as saints row to your decice. This is free for anyone who has a shield tv device and it feels very responsive! This is of course done over the internet, and thus requires a very fast internet connection. If you have an Nvidia gpu on your home computer, this also will let you stream any of your pc games to the device, which works great and is a lot of fun. The last option for games is the download section. The download section lists off games made specifically for the nvidia shield tv, that take advantage of the amazing gpu of the device. Awesome game for the anime fan.
It has a bunch (I believe 52 of them) of characters from shonen mangas. BUT only 39 are playable the rest are aids that you can select to help you like in other fighters but not controlable. If you don't see your favorite anime character show is because it's not from an anime that appear on the shonnen comics.

If you were into anime from the 80s or a fan of newer animes of today then you won't find a better game to test their power.
You have characters like goku and vegeta, ichigo, Lufin, naruto/sasuke/madara to others that were bigger outside the U.S. globally like ruroni kenshin, Seiya from saint seiya/caballeros del zodiaco or more old school like kenshiro.

The PLUS version is fully in Japanese audio BUT all voices have English only subtitles. No dubs no other languages. The menus and everything else is in English so this is the version to get.

There is a story mode which is a nice way to start understanding gameplay mechanics, but is not deep at all. It does add some nice replay value since there are 4 of them. Same story different characters. You have to boost characters and items in this mode, but nothing hard and should be Easy to boost everything.
All boosts aside this won't affect much of online or arcade gameplay. Only cards can affect them and are not required and most won't have them turn on to play multiplayer anyway.
Balanced game this is not. Some characters are better some are meh, but you can master any of them and beat the cpu but online you will need to select better ones if you want to win.

Mix ad match is great. Having my fav characters battle each other is amazing and works great. Especials are awesome, but more famous characters like naruto have better looking specials effect wise.
This game is not for competition fighting, I'm sure in competitions we would only see the sane 6 characters playing.
To unlock characters you need to spend points you get from the story mode or battleing online and then going to the character store to spend the points. No real money, should be fairly easy to unlock them all after 1 story gameplay. After 2-3 hrs on the story you can spend what you got to unlock a bunch of your favorite ones. You need to pass the story levels to unlock more spaces. So if you want to unlock everyone then you need to do the story mode to have all the spaces be available. Takes a few hours only though and will learn how to control all characters more or less.
Most characters use the same control scheme some are close combat others are long range, but button presses are the same.
Ultimates are fairly easy to pull and techniques are easy to do as well.
I highly recommend this game (PLUS) version to any anime fan. The graphics are great, the characters look great and it's a lot of fun.
Online doesn't seem to have many people playing and this was the first weeks of release so don't expect to constantly play just online.
You can coop w someone at your house or online either in story mode or multiplayer so that is cool as well.

You can add easily your own music from your hd in the PS3 version and I did it for the music I wanted to hear from my fav characters and it kinda works because they can get mixed together and you have two singers and sings that don't match when doing ultimate a singing at the same time. I would definitely recommend this headset, especially if your a fan of Call of Duty Ghosts, because the designs and colors on these are very cool!  XBOX ONE COMPATIBILITY UPDATE: I just recently got an Xbox One, and wasn't sure if this headset would work with it because it's not really advertised as being able to do so, but I'm happy to say this headset works great with the Xbox One!  Basically your Xbox One controller acts like an amplifier, so you actually will not use the included amplifier, the RCA audio cables, the USB plug, nor any of the other cables included with this headset, which is awesome! All you need is the headphones themselves, and the single cable that's attached to them. You'll plug that one cable into the bottom of your Official Microsoft Brand Xbox One Controller (generic controllers will not work). Now on your Xbox One dashboard, click the menu button (which was the "Start" button on the 360) click "Settings", to the right and down a bit, click "Devices & Accessories". Select the proper controller. Now click "Volume". You'll see "Headset volume", and "Mic monitoring". Turn these options all the way up, and that's it! I purchased the cheapest version of this headset, The Shadow edition. I say that because the Xbox One controller is already wireless, and delivers the game's audio to your ears while transmitting your mic signals, therefore the wired headset becomes wireless when using it with an Xbox One! column6: Mad Catz Arcade FightStick Tournament Edition 2 for PlayStation 4 and PlayStation 3
column13: Functions great, but leaves some of the asthetics to be desired
column14:
I have had this stick for a little while so far, but I feel that it is appropriate to write a review for others that are as curious as I was about some issues.

First of all I'd like to say I have had experiences with other sticks, such as the infamous Madcatz TE stick and the Qanba Q4RAF. So I may be comparing this stick to those others.

As far as the quality of the components goes, this item is great. It functions equally well with the PS4 and PS3 and even PC. The controls used are pretty much the standard now a days with fighting arcade sticks. The TE 2 features standard Sanwa OBS buttons and a JLF Joystick. For those that don't know, Sanwa along with another company Seimitsu is pretty much ranked among the top Japanese arcade parts manufactures. The TE 2 is accurate as expected, works well and takes a beating. It also includes a detachable cable that can be stored within the stick and I'm sure can be easily replaced through Madcatz if need be. The buttons can also be easily replaced and are fairly inexpensive and found online easily. One of the great things is that Madcatz encourages users to modify the TE 2 to their personal liking. Which means any modifications that include simple button swaps and art swaps are covered under warranty. Though this is a great accomplishment, it also paves the way for some of my biggest problems with the stick.

At currently 200 USD you are basically paying a premium for a niche item. Such a premium price is expected to have premium parts right? Well not exactly. Madcatz unfortunately seems to be stingy with a lot of the aesthetic parts of the stick. First of all, the stick is highly marketed as a mod able stick and personalize to your liking. Typically what needs to be done is you have to order a custom made blank plexi and the print out artwork to match etc. Well the Madcatz stick includes a so called plexi to make things easier. Unfortunately the plexi is in reality an extremely thin sheet of transparency. Literally it feels like one of those things you put on an overhead projector. It scratches terribly easy, and it warps under the stress of simply resting your palms on the stick. For some reason it also creates a strange rainbow effect when pressed against the underlying artwork. The material seems to attract buildup from your sweat like a magnet so it is hard to keep neat and intact. It is to my understanding that the original versions of the TE 2 actually included a plexi which makes it even harder to understand why they would supply such a cheap piece of material.
The Tool that is included with the stick isn't the best either. I suppose it would be handy in a situation where you wouldn't have something more practical with you, but the screws that come stock with the TE2 are fairly tight and hard to unscrew, at least for the first time with just the tool alone. One of the screws which holds the side panels in place is also misaligned in some manner so it doesn't sit flush with the rest of the bezel. Some of the side and top bezels also don't seem to lie flush against the outer case so it feels strange when you put your hand on certain parts. I suppose it isn't a huge game breaking issue, but when added up it makes me feel slightly cheated for the money that needs to be put on the table for one of these things.

Many of the issues that bothered me are quite minor, but I specifically bought this stick in order to personalize it and thought it would be simple to do so. Unfortunately I was unsatisfied with the plexi and I will have to spend some extra money to bring it up to my standards. For anyone else that's interested check out Art's Hobbies. He provides some nice replacement plexis.
That being said, I feel like I may have overpaid a bit given the quality of some of the materials. The design is great, but I don't understand why Madcatz would provide such mediocre panels. Even so, I am fairly happy with pretty much the rest of theTE 2. I'd recommend it as a great stick but for those looking to customize be prepared to put a little more effort.

Now as for the joystick itself. It's not bad for around $40. I played around with it a little before I took it apart, and it performed decently with some of the games I tried it with. It's not perfect, but I wouldn't expect it to be. But I wasn't missing tons of inputs or anything.

One issue with the stock joystick is that the buttons activate directly onto a circuit board. Which seems like a pretty big design flaw. Eventually the board will break being used under that kind of stress. So as a stock joystick this thing is probably not built to last. Bur this is likely a symptom of the price point.

Taken for what it is, this joystick is almost tailor made for modding. So that's what I've based my review on. If you just want a cheap joystick for all of your fighters and whatnot, then you might want to take a star off of the review score at your discretion. It's a cheap enough stick, but one that's liable to break on you after enough use.

You take control of Johnny Gat or Kenize Kensington via switching at the Ultor HQ in Hell. yes you are in Hell, no surprise huh, especially with all the crime you did in all the previous games. Controls are tight and easily adjusted via the options.Camera has improved greatly and replayablity is something you will and want to do. Side quests and activities are toned down which will appeal to new comers and casuals alike. The game is an easy 8 to 10 hours for activities and main story, which is not bad for an expansion. The game feels more like a quasi sequel than expansion which is also a plus.

The Bad:
Activities and side quests are repetitive, however there is not that many activities which is I would say a plus. Salvation: prevent souls from leaving and/or falling to hell. Torment Fraud: a spin on insurance fraud where you take control of a husk and ram into hell cars in exchanged for time served. HellBlazing: aerial timed race using the wings acquired from Lucifer's Halo. Extraction: a Base takeover type activity along with a few others. I wished it was a bit longer but at this point I am nitpicking.

The Nerdy:
Johnny Gat and Kenize are voiced by their previous Voice Actors. Johnny Gat's voice actor, Daniel Dae Kim, has voiced the title character since SR1 and is also on Hawaii Five-0. This is first time you play a preexisting character rather than forging a new one. No Cheats or radio stations in this game. Dex is back as a revenge quest. Finally the title is a play on Meat Loaf's Bat Outta Hell album title.

Conclusion:
I highly recommend this game for fans and casuals alike. It is worth the money and is a satisfying expansion to a wonderfully fun franchise. I give it a 5 outta 5!derfully fun franchise. I give it a 5 outta 5!

column6: Tera - Exclusively @ Best Buy - The Blue Roan Mount
column14:
I purchased a physical, factory-sealed Best-Buy edition of TERA in July 2015 to obtain the Founder's code inside.

Purchasing a physical copy of TERA and redeeming the code on the back of the included manual (be sure to submit it a second time in reverse as well) unlocks Founder status for the account. Three additional bank slots, six additional character slots, 20 additional broker slots, a 280-speed mount, the Founder title and assorted trinkets, all account-wide (across all servers and characters). In addition, you'll receive a BoE (tradeable) 280-speed mount worth north of 10k gold at time of posting.

The Best Buy edition also includes a 255-speed Blue Roan mount that is, honestly, completely useless unless you're the type who simply *must* have every mount in the game. The Blue Roan is account-wide as well.

So, if you already enjoy TERA and want to either: A) make tons of alts -- or B) eliminate the worry of storage space, I recommend the purchase. This is much cheaper than individually purchasing the included items with En Masse's EMP and makes the inventory-management aspects of the game much less of a hassle. If the standard copy of the game is available (and cheaper), you could potentially save yourself a couple dollars.

I take a star off the review because of TERA's design. You'll love the active combat and potentially the aesthetic of TERA. The community varies, as should be expected in any MMO, but if you're into RP or ERP you'll find a home here.

This is where the fun ends.

Leveling is a grindfest (like many MMORPGs). Quests are utterly horrendous, fetch, repetitive, backtracking drivel (so terrible, they removed side quests altogether in the level 60+ areas later added in an expansion). The active combat is refreshing at first, but the developers fail to capitalize on it with simple and monotonous monster/boss AI and mechanics. If you're into quickly leveling, expect to run the same low-end dungeons 10-15 times, each, per character.

Endgame is the worst example of grindfest across the myriad MMORPGs I've dabbled in over the years. Endgame bosses use re-hashed skins and mechanics from low-end dungeons. With each update, the developer's MO is to remove 3-6 dungeons (this is unusual), add or slightly tweak 2-4, and force players to run the same one or two ad nauseam for weeks to "earn" the highest end gear. Within a few months, new gear and a new high-end dungeon will be out, allowing you the opportunity to start the process from scratch again.

By endgame, you'll be committed to either 2-6 hours of dailies in an attempt to gear or 2-6 hours of easier dailies across your 6-8 alts to mine currency. You'll absolutely need a guild to break the monotony with their (hopefully) entertaining antics on Comms.

Or -- if your time is more valuable than your money -- you can pay-to-win. Expect to pay a lot. Many do.

If earning a place at the top through commitment, time and repetitive gameplay (and/or a lot of cash) is your thing, TERA is for you. If you want to casually (or not so casually) roleplay a berserking badger, saintly rock-man, or loli prostitute, TERA is for you. If you want to try the combat mechanics without the commitment, you've no need to spend any money. TERA's F2P. Give it a download and experience the breadth of the universe before making a purchase.

column13: Running, Loading Screen, Running, Loading Screen.....
column14:
It's not really an open world game. You're restricted to completing quests in order of level of difficulty. There's no sense of awe in exploration, because it's an endless chain of running and fast traveling to each quest. You must manually select your next quest every time, as the game chooses them for you in the wrong order, again, every time.

Loading Screen Simulator : There's a short loading screen to check your quests, your map, your inventory. There's a loading screen to talk to merchants, a loading screen for people giving you quests, a long loading screen to 'fast' travel, and an even longer loading screen to start the game. Every time you boot it up you are forced to watch a CD project red advertisement, then wait for the start up menu to load, then start your game save load. It's the longest wait i've ever seen to get to a game.

You cannot fast travel anywhere until you've been there first.

You cannot fast travel anywhere but to sign posts.

You must physically be at a sign post to fast travel.

Why can't you fast travel anywhere at any time from any place? running to a sign post. fast travel loading screen. running from a sign post.

When checking your map to find the destination of your quest, there's no arrow indicating in which direction it is, so you must manually scan the map in every direction to find the quest marker. unbelievable. You must do this over, and over and over again. which direction is the quest marker? how many seconds will you waste looking for it each time? your results may vary.

Done talking to an npc? You must watch a cutscene of geralt saying farewell every single time before you can leave.

Lag simulaor. The game has constant frame rate issues for no reason. In combat, near water, in a marsh or swamp? you're screwed.

Yes, the game has good graphics, but plenty of other games do this at a stable framerate. It's almost like they sabotaged the console ports so Nvidia could sell graphics cards. There's no justification for this garbage. The game is simply unfinished. They forced it out the door too early.

Every time the game lagged, it left me wondering why, because nothing impressive is ever going on on screen when it does.

Horse AI. god save us. When you whistle to summon your horse, instead of galloping up to you, it walks up to you, forcing you to turn around and run to it. The horse always seems to spawn behind you, forcing you to retrace your steps. the horse should sprint up to you and let you jump onto it like you're legolas. Nope.

The horse will stop running for no reason. again and again and again. I bet it did it to me over 500 times. Sometimes it spawns stuck inside a house or any other piece of geometry. It refuses to jump over obstacles, instead running right into them. other times, rarely, it works flawlessly.

Animal Abuse. You're forced to make roach carry 'trophies' strapped to the saddle in order to get the combat, gold, or experience bonus they provide. What jerk forces his horse to carry a massive gryphon head everywhere for no reason? You don't even unequip your saddle bags when participating in races. strikingly lazy.

Instead of building a relationship with your horse, you improve it's abilities by equipping new saddles and saddlebags. Even of the saddle is bigger, your horse gains stamina. ridiculous.

Your relationship with roach should have been one of the best parts of the game, and instead it's the worst. Roach doesn't even know what roads to take when you're riding. Nothing works. Nothing ever friken works.

And because roach doesn't know which road to take, you're forced to constantly check your minimap so you know when and where to turn. It makes riding your horse even more of a chore than it already is.

Because you need experience to level up, you can't turn down any quest, meaning youcan't make any meaningful choices, yet the developers still leave the option to tell people to go screw themselves.

Geralt is constantly trying to be an jerk by telling people he doesn't care or isn't interested in the stories they tell him when he takes a quest. TMI. TMI. TMI. Does he need to be rude to everyone, at all times? These people are explaining their problems to you and offering you money for your help. oh wait, 'witchers are impatient'.

chest pieces made out of cloth have better defense stats than the cool looking chainmail armor you start out with?

Wild Hunt. An endless hunt for people again and again and again. The plot never changes, you're always wandering around searching for something, everyone wants you to find someone or something for them, a person, a goat, a frying pan, etc, etc. run here looking, run there looking.

Using witcher senses can sometimes be frustrating to follow the trail ahead of you, as it is often to faint to spot, and the game often requires you to spot things in order, which causes trouble if you missed something.

There's texture pop in too, usually in cities. The game often also blurs and freezes for a short time, also usually in cities.

When you find the legendary tools of a derelict and monster guarded forge in skellige, instead of giving these tools to your friends in skellige, you rob them and give it to some random dwarf craftsman in another country. Stealing skellige's heritage? Unbelievably moronic.

You can equip mutagens. I never did this, because it makes no sense. As far as I understood, whichers are bonded with mutagens as children, as part of their painful transformation into witchers. So how can geralt equip new ones and unequip old ones on a whim now?

Combat can also be frustrating when you get locking into taking damage. Geralt winces as he gets hit over and over and over again without any way to roll out of range or parry / block incoming attacks. One complete, everything was ready, I didn't have to download and reinstall a single game or app. it was all there including P.T. The only thing extra I had to do was Activate As My Primary PS4 and Restore the License's so I can play certain games again (like Batman Arkham Knight). But that's it. During the entire process I kept checking to see if there was any overheating, and there was none. The PS4 gets warm, but no more warmer than it did with the regular HD that it came with. For those who are still concerned with heat, just place the PS4 on a Laptop Cooler. They are very cheap, it covers the entire body of the PS4 and works perfectly. I had one collecting dust and I use it as a precaution. Although it was never really needed, but it does keep the system cooler which is a good thing. if your worried about USB ports (which a Laptop Cooler uses) just get the 5 USB port adapter.. however do not use the 5 USB port adapter when restoring your PS4 after upgrading your Hard Drive. column13: Some simmers will love it, others will hate it
column14: After reading several negative reviews about the game, I was on the fence about buying this game. It seemed like a lot of simmers hated it compared to the sims3. I've been playing sims since the original sims and was expecting the sims4 to be immaculate. The game does deliver in some areas,  but in others it makes me want to chunk my laptop out the window.  Here's my list of pros/cons:  1) create a sim pro: this is by far the best CAS. I love the graphics and the push/pull effects. Clothes are nice too. Con: you can't really customize colors and patterns. But the clothes are actually modern clothes and have good color choices so this doesn't bother me.  2) building houses pro: you can pickup rooms and move them instead of demolishing them if your not happy with placement. The doors and windows are way better than sims3. You can have average wall height or high celings with one click instead of building two stories to make a high celings. Cons: it is hard as hell to get use to! It's basically the same as sims3, but on crack. I find myself making walls without even clicking on the lot. The camera is way different than sims 3 too. You can either look flat at your house or straight on top of the house. No camera tilting like sims3. Which is a pain when building. 3) the world. I love how they set up the world. There is 3 neighborhoods to choose from and your not limited to that neighborhood like the other sims games. You can live in one area then go to the park in another.  Con: there's not a town view like sims3. Each neighborhood has 4 buildings you can visit (gym, library, ect) and you have to "travel" to get there. No cars.  4) live sim mode. Pro: there are so many more interactions and sims do seem to tend to themselves. I'm not constantly clicking the toliet or fridge to help keep them maintained they do take the initiative to do stuff on their own. Con: you can't really influence them at work/school like "make new friends" "suck up to boss"to help boost their levels of achievement or gain friends. I made a child and after 1 sims week he still had 0 relationships other than his parents. So you actually have to make an effort to be social. 5) items. Pro: there is ALOT of stuff that comes with the sims4 base game. There is a little something for every sim. Some stuff that would only be available through and expansion pack (like the piano in late night) now comes with the base game. You can have anything from a wood workers bench to a rocketship. Cons: I personally haven't missed anything except for there's no cars, and no swings or bikes for children. But that doesn't effect me. However someone else might have been wanting something that wasn't included.  There is several other things I could write about but let's face it, neither of us have all day. My advise would be to each some videos on YouTube so you can kind of see the sims4 in action. Like I said before, there's alot of negative reviews about this game. But I really enjoy playing it.   Also, I ordered this game almost a year after it had been released hoping EA would have worked some of the bugs out. Well, right off the bat it said I had to update the game to the latest patch or I couldn't play it. It took SIX HOURS TO UPDATE! I had several problems with it throwing out an error codr, I had to update it in safe mode just to get the update to work. So anyone who is purchasing it now... you have been warned.  Hope this helps =)

As you can assume, this thing does a great job of playing Vita games on a TV, rather than making a cable for the original Vita portable which also had the video scaler built into it. I'm glad that they did, as I much prefer using the wireless Dual Shock 3/4 controllers rather than have a portable system with a bulky cable sticking out the back like the PSP did.

It's capable of scaling the games from their native resolution of 960x544 to either 480p, 720p or 1080i (NOT 1080p). It starts out of the box in 480p for compatibility, and you can easily change the resolution in the Settings app to suit your display. 720p is probably the best choice for action games as it's a progressive resolution, but you will get (slightly) better picture quality out of 1080i.

This little device is pretty slick. It's quite tiny, with the length being just enough to harbor the power jack, HDMI port, USB port, Vita memory card and power button. The shorter side harbors the physical game slot.

The DC adapter has been done right where it doesn't terminate in a wall wart, but instead has the AC section in the middle of the cable.

One annoyance I have with the physical design, is that the game card slot is designed just like it is on the Vita. You use your fingernail to pull out the dust cover that's permanently attached by two pieces of rubberized plastic and push the game in, making it nearly impossible to do with one hand. I would have much rather had a hinged cartridge slot in place of that so you could just push and click the game into place.

This thing can also stream video from your PS4, so you can play your PS4 from another room with this thing hooked up. I don't currently own a PS4 though, so I can't really talk at length about that. All I can say is that the PS4 and PSTV support Wireless N... but you probably won't have a great streaming experience unless both of them are hooked up via Gigabit Ethernet which is highly impracticalin most cases.

The reason behind the 4 star rating: Not every game that's released for the Vita is compatible with this system. I can certainly understand games that specifically require the touch interface to not be compatible for obvious reasons, but it's not limited to those games. It's up to the developers whether or not they want to support the PSTV, and even some games that have been made compatible in Japan, NEVER get updated in other regions (examples such as Ys: Memories of Celceta and Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth 1).

This same issue reaches to PSP and PS1 Classics where most of them are not compatible, even though there's no foreseeable reason why they're not.

The other negative thing I've noticed is the cut and dry version of the PS Store on the device. You're unable to see if there are sales going on for any products when you're browsing the store on the PSTV, but you're more than able to do so on the Vita handheld or the Playstation Store's website. I'm not sure why the differentiation between the app stores, but it certainly does annoy me now that I've seen them side by side.

Overall, for the prices these things go for now, they're a great value, especially for games that beg to be on a larger screen. I would say the original price of $100-120 was ludicrous for what this thing is, but now that they're almost universally available for less than $50? It's a worthwhile appliance.

column14: A love letter to people who grew up with Dragonball, and Dragonball Z. Don't let the title fool you, this has some Dragonball in it as well, just a little mind you, but still great attention to detail in the scenes, and it gives you a better understanding of the characters. Those who grew up with Z only will probably be disappointed this doesn't get to the more iconic frieza fight (I'd for one love a sequel too) but to learn more about the characters, and how weak they started out really makes the saiyans a more daunting foe, as well as the fact they bring back lesser known moves from Z, such as the evil containment wave. These were big in Dragonball, but later in Z got kind of overshadowed by more impressive attacks. If you're a fan of either show though, you'll really appreciate it. The gameplay itself is standard turn based RPG, it is possible to grind easily as you he's after every level gained, but not needed to beat anyone in the game really, especially if you want a challenge. The moves have flashy demonstrations and a good balance of special vs. standard attacks. I'd give this game a 5 star simply for the attention to detail in the lore, as well as the art, both sprite and portrait, and being a solid game gameplay wise. Would love a sequel in the way, and even a prequel to start from the beginning of Dragonball.

While the Xbox One is has met a large amount of criticism from its release date to current, I believe it is a well refined product worthy of some praise. Here are a quick list of pros and cons that I found from using it for about a month now.

Pros
- The difference in graphics between the 360 and the One are night and day. Anything from frame rate to clarity to resolution is vastly improved. This allows those 1080p TVs do do what they were made for.
- The sleek design and interface are crisp, clean, and simple. It did take some getting used to when finding most of the systems functions as Ive been using the 360 for over 4 years.
- The game selection is finally becoming something. With all of the titles currently released and the titles that have been announced as being in the works or in development for the One, this system has become a must have for all counsel gaming fans.

Cons
- Between the space taken up from the operating system and the fact that each game you play must first be downloaded, the 500gb counsel is woefully short on storage space. That being said, for anyone hoping to oven more than 10 or so games needs to have the 1tb counsel or an external storage for their 500gb counsel.
- While playing Far Cry 4, I found that while the overall graphics are vastly improved (which allows the game to shine for what it is whereas the 360 ruins it), I noticed that the frame rate did suffer in some larger gunfights or exploration.

The Halo MCC is a masterpiece. As a rather casual Halo fan having played each game back when each was released, this collection is by far the best thing to happen to the Halo franchise yet. Its remastered soundtracks and cut-scenes improve the overall theatrical feeling of the games beyond what words can describe. I have not a single regret about buying this bundle.

column6: The Legend of Zelda: The Wind Waker HD
column14:
This is a great game! The toony art style might not be for everyone, I understand that, but it is still a great adventure and story.

It looks really beautiful in high definition. The lighting especially is really nice looking and majestic.

The controls are really a nice change and an improvement. Being able to swap your inventory with a touch screen is great and the sea chart feels like it was made for the game pad. This remaster is more than just visuals!

Hero mode is a nice addition to make the game a little more challenging for older players and people who have played this game before. It makes it so that there are no hearts to be found in the world ( there are still heart pieces) and enemies deal double the damage. Good luck taking on the final boss in this mode! Good thing you can turn it on or off any time through out the game.

The swift sail is a very handy addition allowing you to change the direction of the wind without using the windwaker. It also greatly speeds up the time it takes to travel. One of the draw backs of this is that it makes the world feel small! It's not a complaint it's just hard not to notice this effect.

This game is all about the story and the game play. The gameplay is great especially with the new controls and the story is grand as always.

This game belongs in my greatest games of all time list. But, I don't blame you if the cartoon art style isn't for you.

column6: Thrustmaster TX Racing Wheel Ferrari 458 Italia Edition
column13: Great wheel, great value (especially for XB1). Save for the add-ons, they really turn it up to 11.
column14:
Great wheel. I used to have a force GT, which was a great all around good value. As soon as I tried this wheel I could not believed the level of realisim and feedback one gets. I've used it in Forza 5, Dirt Rally and most recently Horizon 2. On horizon 2 the Force feedback really shines thru.

I do have to admid however that the stock configuration is not ideal. The standard wheel feels toy like. Too plastic. The pedals are not bad, if you don't miss the 3 pedal. And yes, mine broke too. I got a replacement back within a week free of charge. Those things happen.

My setup has the TH8A shifter, T3PA pedals, and the Ferrari GTE wheel. All toghether it comes to be a little on the expensive side, but you can minimize cost by looking around for deals. All things considered this setup ultimatelly comes up to be slightly lower, or at worst at the same price as the competition from what I've seen. Also if you are a racing fan, it is a small price to pay for the experience, as it is safer and way cheaper than real racing. :P
I have the F1 wheel too, but I haven't used much since I mostly do Horizon now a days. Hopefully when Forza 6 comes, I'll be hable to give it some hours.

For the seat frame, I opted to build my own. A couple of boards from a hardware store and some screws are cheaper than any decent setup I saw online. It may not look pretty, but then again I don't think a racing seat and some tubes look pretty in any living room either. I painted mine mat black, and when lights are off, all I see is the screen. Building it yourself, you can setup your sitting possition as you like, I went for something similar to an LMP/F1 seating possition. it is nice.

*** Make sure, whatever the base you use for it it is sturdy, not only strong, but also stiff. The forced feedback is really strong, really strong. It gives real feel and feedback, think about turning the wheels in a non powersteered car. If the frame is not sturdy it will deflect and you will loose some of the feel. You can dial down the feedback, but according to me, if you are paying that much for a setup you might as well get the most out of it. ***

To recap. Great wheel, great value (especially for XB1), considered what is on the market. If you can, save for the add-ons, they really turn it up to 11. Sturdy base needed.

column6: Adventure Time: Hey Ice King! Why'd you steal our garbage ?!
column13: A fun and cute game for all ages. But, don't expect a challenge!
column14:
Just a disclaimer: this review is coming from someone in their late 30s who has seen the show Adventure Time, but could not be considered a huge fan of it. However, I am a gamer...so there's that.

I was attracted to this game because of the demo I downloaded on the Nintendo 3DS e-shop. It reminded me of a cross between Zelda 2 and the old Dragon Warrior games on the NES. It has the top-down view when traveling between lands, with random battles popping up while walking. Then, it switches to a side-scroller when going through towns or dungeons.
The art is quite cute, and the graphics are done nicely; resembling the cartoon. There is decent humor that is on par with the show as well.
The 3D is done quite well also.

I enjoyed the game, however I found it to be quite easy...resulting in the 4 star rating. There is not a lot of difficulty, but this is most likely geared toward someone much younger than me. The biggest challenge comes from trying to figure out where to go to next, with back-tracking taking up a considerable amount of time. Although I found the revisiting of areas somewhat annoying, it helped make the game last longer.

I really liked the music used throughout, especially in the "haunted woods" levels. I also liked the variety of settings each stage takes place in. The characters you interact with are both funny and cute.

I would recommend this as a light-hearted game that anyone could pick up and enjoy, especially if you like the old adventure games like Zelda and Actraiser. It seems to be made for younger gamers, due to the difficulty level, but it shouldn't distract anyone from giving it a try!

TLDR: I'm fairly dissapointed in the Game. Its extremly easy and does not require any thinking.

The first problem any trading game has, is the balance between giving the Player enough feedback so he always knows whats going on and still not making the game too easy by giving too much info.
The second problem any trading game has is to balance the degree of automisation, so it doesnt become a chore, and the amount of needed management, so it doesnt become boring.

Patrician IV fails both of these tasks by being "too user friendly".
The trading Screen has for each tradegood a bar with 4 stages, that shows how much is in stock in the city, which directly translates to the price being given. This is very easy to understand and makes the player just buy everything that has 2 bars or more and sell everything in his ship that has 1 or 0 bars. The production of goods is decently distributed, meaning you almost never produce 2 things in adjacent cities and never in 3 adjacent cities. So there is no thinking involved, no "valuable trade route finding" or anything, the player can just go from any random port the next random port, buy anything thats fairly cheap and sell it in the next. Even if he doesnt get to sell something he can always just hold on to it for the next port, the ships have huge loading capacities and the player enough money to buy anything from the start so there is no opportunity cost, buy it all. Money flows like crazy.

However, this is not even needed, since the player can make traderoutes and just tell the AI to "Auto-Trade" any good the ai wants to. This means that the AI does EXACTLY the same thing of buying anything cheap and selling anything non-cheap, only that the player doesnt need to do anything anymore besides press the spacebar for 10x speed and watch the hundreds of thousands of gold pile up in his account every 5 minutes real time or so. I just started a new game, played a little more than an hour and now have a tradefleet of about 10 Ships, Am Producing 6 Goods in 3 Cities and still have almost a million in the bank. (The Cog, the biggest Ship in the early game, costs ~50k, so 1 Million means you have basically unlimited money.)

The Production is weak, meaning that usually you need to build a resource in a city and then the final product (never consisting of more than one raw-material) in a different city for no other reason than the game mechanic. (why cant I make meat in Lübeck, is Lübeck a hostile environment to cows? Why can't I produce beer in Stockholm, do the Sweedish people not know how to make beer and are entirely resistant to learning it?) However, this is still not hard (even though the Trade-Route-Screen could use a major rehaul and, when doing anything but the automated-trade-thing mentioned earlier quite user unfriendly and requires more thinking to press the right buttons, than thinking about the trade route is required) and the effect is having even more money, since for example produced meat is worth so much money, that even selling it in the meat-abundant-city where you produce it (where anyone produces it, due to the mechanic mentioned before) makes a huge profit.

All in all, the game is just way too easy, the player has way too much money, "minmaxing" or fiddling with the own traderoutes is not necessary since the most complicated traderoute will most likely not yield as much as the "trade all" and even if it did, the "trade all" route requires about 8 Clicks and, in opposition to the own traderoute, which you spent so much time on creating, will work forever, since the AI automatically adapts to changes in the economy.

So besides the mechanics of the game what else is there to say?

The Graphics are somewhat decent, its not beautiful, but for an economic/trading Sim, its OK, except that I find the Cities to look horrible. EVERY City is build like aCrecent around the harbour, so theres the harbour and then theres a ring of buildings, followed by another ring of buildings and followed by the ROUND city walls. If it gets extended, it gets a 3rd ring of building. THIS IS NOT WHAT CITIES LOOK LIKE! Thank god you will spend the enire game looking at the mapscreen, which is remarkably undetailed for a game where you spend about 90% of your time staring at it (even if you trade yourself, you dont need to enter the cities for that, goodsexchange can be done via the map) like this and, even though the ONLY valid information on it is the cities, these are drawn quite small.

Sound is ok, meaning there is none, except the constant ringing of a bell when a Ship enters the harbour which you will either hate to your guts or simply not hear at all anymore after some time which makes the whole excercise rather pointless, and the dialogs of the other Merchants which always say the same (even though they have different voices, so someone actually thought it would be a good idea to get 6 voiceactors or so, and have them all say the same exact same thing.) become repetetive after the first half an hour, but can be clicked away.

There is a campaign, which is a "slow" tutorial, meaning it has 0 Story (Spoiler: Youre a merchant. Your advisor is your Uncle. Thats all.) introduces all the mechanics over the couse of a couple of hours and basically works excatly like the free game, only that it gives you missions like "reach this-or-that-rank" which you automatically succeed in by just playing the game or holding the spacebar)

Combat is just plain bad, nothing more to say. You have rather little influence on it and even if you did, it would still be boring. Its just up to 6 Ships (3 each side) circling each other and shooting every couple of seconds while you stare at your watch, wondering when its finally over.

Also, there is very little variety to the gameplay. Trading one resource feels like trading the other, since ships are not specialized in resources but carry everthing. Producing one product feels like any other, since its always just made from one other Resource. Theres only 3 Ships in the beginning, and while it gets a LITTLE more varied later on, by that time you will have ~30 Cogs cruising the seas, each and every one doing the same thing.
Perfect!!!
It's a fun game. I really enjoy playing it.

The Far Cry games were reinvented twice and each time they were nothing short of gold. Far Cry 4 does not see a return of this reinvention strategy but it does improve upon the feel of the last game. Originally I enjoyed stumbling upon a stray captive and guard and the occasional gunfight was even exciting but by far, the worst thing about this game, was the endless gunfire. If you happen to be exploring near one of the rebel/army shootouts, the distant gunfire will never stop unless you run away or hunt them down and kill everyone there. Just assisting the rebels would give you any peace because soon after, they will start wildly shooting into the air and once again, never stop. It can really be a headache at times and with how often these events pop up in the environment, headaches are ensue.

Overall I love the game but I wish they had done just a bit more refining. Still worth 5 starts though
